posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
We recently tuned our arm using 0 as the horizontal and 90 as straight up using signal logger and sysid.  When we moved the arm slightly past 90 degrees it took off towards the 180 degree direction.

At first we were a bit confused and then we realized that maybe kg (which would act on the cosine of the angle) is turning into a negative value and driving the arm down the other end.

If that is the case can it be configured to behave as if 100 degree were just 80 on the other side.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

If that is the case can it be configured to behave as if 100 degree were just 80 on the other side.

This would be incorrect behavior, and would cause what you’re seeing to get worse rather than fixing it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Right cause  negative voltage would counteract gravity on the other side.

Back to my checks then.

Thanks for the sanity check oblarg

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: With zeroing and another run on sysId the gains  we got better results below 90 but when we go above 90 our voltage ended up being a steady positive .2 volts which is roughly our kg value.  We were in a holding state but it looks like the armcosine setting is not working past 90

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Just to confirm, you have your arm set up so it reports a position of 0 when horizontally forward, and 0.25 when vertically up?

If you set all your other feedforward gains to 0 except kG and the GravityType, you can look at the getClosedLoopFeedForward() signal to see the output of kG. That value should be positive when the arm is between (-0.25, 0.25) rotations, and negative when between (0.25, 0.75) rotations.

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
0 on the horizontal and 0.25 vertically up.

I’ll give that a try in the morning Thanks.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So in the Sim I have the arm at 66 degrees.  The contribution to kG should be 0.22122 * cos (66 deg).  Or approximately 0.089958.  The output from getClosedLoopFeedforward while holding is 0.190000

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I also have UseClosedLoop sign for Ks and not useVelocity Sign

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
I can confirm on hardware by using getClosedLoopFeedforward.  I’m an getting a constant gravity compensation of kg and not kg * cos theta.  Arm_Cosine is set.

I’ve attached my config.json file for the settings

talonfxvers.c-14-configs.json (59.2 KB)

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So I turned off kg in the Slotconfig and calculated it manually and added it to the withFeedforward in the Control method and not I’m getting correct values.  Still need to test on real thing.  Works in sim

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

So in the Sim I have the arm at 66 degrees. The contribution to kG should be 0.22122 * cos (66 deg). Or approximately 0.089958. The output from getClosedLoopFeedforward while holding is 0.190000

That does not at all match what I see in simulation. If I move my simulated motor to 0.183 rotations (66 deg), with kG at 0.22122, I see the closed loop feedforward report 0.09 V: image 1718×788 24.1 KB

image 1718×788 24.1 KB

image 1718×788 24.1 KB

Note that arm kG is a feedback term, so it uses the current motor position to calculate the feedforward output.

narmstro:

I’ve attached my config.json file for the settings

Those configs have a lot more than just kG enabled, which muddies the waters.

Can you either capture a hoot log of when the issue reproduces, or capture a plot in Tuner X of the Talon FX “Position” and “PIDMotorVoltage_FeedForward” signals when kS = kV = kA = 0? You should just have kP, kG, and the GravityType set in your slot configs.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: To clarify terminology a bit: kG is a linearizer that may be computed either as a feedforward or as a feedback.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Should my discontinuity point be set to 0.25 (90 degrees) or 0.5?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
Oh I just noticed, you’re using a RemoteCANcoder? Is that CANcoder absolute with the mechanism? If so, you shouldn’t be setting the SensorToMechanismRatio, as the CANcoder position gets divided by that. The SensorToMechanismRatio should only reflect any gearing between the sensor (which is the CANcoder in the case of RemoteCANcoder) and the mechanism.

The discontinuity point should be set to the center of the range of motion that is not achievable by your arm. See the API documentation for more information.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: You mean achievable?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: No, I mean unachievable. The discontinuity point is the point at which the absolute position jumps from x to x-1 (or vice versa). See the API documentation for more information.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
This?

For example, consider an arm which can travel from -0.2 to 0.6 rotations with a little leeway, where 0 is horizontally forward. Since -0.2 rotations has the same absolute position as 0.8 rotations, we can say that the arm typically does not travel in the range (0.6, 0.8) rotations. As a result, the discontinuity point would be the center of that range, which is 0.7 rotations. This results in an absolute sensor range of [-0.3, 0.7) rotations.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: So say our arm goes from -0.1 to 0.5 rotations. So that discontinuity range would be 0.5 to 0.6. Half of that is 0.7.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: I’m assuming that was a typo, the discontinuity range would be from 0.5 to 0.9 (since -0.1 corresponds to 0.9, add one rotation). But yes, the discontinuity point would be 0.7 rotations.
